text: (upbeat music)
I'm extremely honored to be included
in this year's Chemical and Engineering News Talented 12,
and have been enjoying the talk so far.
I look forward to hearing from the other honorees
later today.
That's a slide, here we go.
Okay, so I like to start my talk by first
introducing my research background.
I completed my undergraduate degree in chemical engineering
from Washington University in St. Louis.
And which is also where I'm from.
And in my senior year,
I had the opportunity to complete a senior thesis
with the faculty advisor who would later become
my PhD advisor, Dr. Jun.
And during my PhD, I used surface chemistry techniques
to examine interfacial reactions of nanomaterials and water
and how nanomaterials could potentially be used
to improve water treatment processes.
And then after my PhD completed,
I moved to California to work with Dr. Sedlak
at UC Berkeley investigating new materials
for urban storm water treatment,
which I'll talk about later on in my talk today.
And now I'm an assistant professor
in the Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering
at the University of Washington in Seattle.
So I'd like to frame my talk by thinking about
the urban water,
thinking about urban water sustainability.
Traditionally, environmental engineers
have viewed the urban water supply in a linear approach
where drinking water sources are used, treated,
and then discharged.
And this current paradigm is not sustainable
for growing populations and urbanization.
To protect this resource,
a more sustainable approach would be to close this loop
and recycle waste streams back to the consumer.
And in order to do this, we would of course need
to use a more advanced series of treatment processes.
However, as you can imagine,
there are some challenges to doing this,
which is predominantly the presence of contaminants
that persists even after the series
of advanced treatment processes
that will pose a threat to both human
and environmental health.
So my group, the Aquatic Innovations
in Materials Science Lab,
is creating new technologies to address these problems
in the urban water sector.
My research bridges material science and surface chemistry
with environmental engineering to investigate new ways
to increase urban water supply sustainability.
So I'd like to present two case studies
during my talk today that shows how our group is
working to address these problems.
And the first focus is on stormwater management.
So growing up in St. Louis and, you know,
going to school in St. Louis,
this was my experience with rain
is that we had too much of it.
This is a picture picture of the St. Louis Arch
and the Mississippi River nearby
that's undergoing flooding due to excess rain.
And then when I moved to California
to conduct my postdoc research,
I had another experience with rain
and that there was too little of it.
So when I was there in 2016,
California had one of the worst drought years on record.
And now that I live in Seattle,
my dog, Lucy and I are intimately familiar with rain.
Okay, so again, let's think about this linear approach
of how we even view stormwater,
and that is typically a nuisance,
especially in urbanized areas
with a large impervious surface coverage.
The excess runoff will lead to street flooding,
and so typically what's done
is we just conveyed the stormwater off the road
and it's sent to discharging waters.
And said better storm water management approaches
would be to create more centralized
and decentralized low impact systems,
such as rain gardens that can help
both convey stormwater off the road
and promote local groundwater recharge.
Especially again, in these highly dense,
urban populated areas.
And alternative uses for urban stormwater
could even be purchased like this,
where we could locally harvest stormwater
to use to irrigate our lawns,
and even to irrigate parks,
and in cases of drought and extreme cases,
we can use urban storm water as a drinking water resource.
But before we can realize these more sustainable approaches
to urban stormwater management,
we have to address the presence of contaminants
in urban stormwater.
So here are two examples of sources of contaminants
that can exist in both urban and suburban conditions.
And that's due to interactions with the stormwater
with various surfaces as it travels throughout the streets.
And then eventually through storm drains
down to receiving bodies of water.
So let's, for example,
take a look at a bioretention pond
that's set in an urban area
that's experiencing a storm event.
You'll have an influx of contaminants
into the bioretention pond that need to be treated.
And you can take advantage of existing processes,
such as microbial degradation,
and filtration of large particles and stormwater,
as well as some natural filtration processes
of conventional media, like sand and gravel.
But my research group is looking at ways
to implement engineered material
and taking advantage of modifications of conventional media
to help enhance stormwater contaminant
in these bioretention ponds
and in other drain stormwater infrastructure.
So one example was the coffee biochar
that was mentioned in the C&EN feature.
And so ultimately what we're doing is
thinking about the intended application of our materials
and thinking about the way we want them to interact
with the contaminants of interest.
So our group is essentially designing these materials
and then synthesizing them in lab,
applying the surface chemistry techniques
that I employed during my PhD and postdoc studies,
and then eventually applying them to treat water
at the lab scale,
and then eventually piloting these materials
to treat real urban stormwater.
The other case study I want to discuss
is focused on presence of contaminants
and from wastewater discharge.
So one particular class of contaminants
that we are interested in because they're so persistent
are these per and polyfluoroalkyl substances, or PFAS.
They're also dubbed the forever chemicals.
These synthetic compounds were created for
firefighting foams meant to extinguish liquid flames.
So at training areas like the picture shown here,
use of this foam would result in
large groundwater contamination of compounds
that have similar structures
to the two compounds on this slide.
And these compounds are also acutely toxic
and can contribute to immunotoxicity, endocrine disruption,
and potentially cancer.
And unfortunately,
it's not just this firefighting foam
that these compounds exist in.
They are so useful in many other applications,
such as nonstick coating of pans and skillets,
as well as water-resistant outerwear.
And so they're starting to be used,
or they have been used historically for many applications.
And unfortunately these compounds are so persistent
that they are resistant to microbial degradation.
They are resistant to natural degradation by UV light.
And they are even resistant to degradation
by traditional chemical disinfectants.
And also, unfortunately for us,
they're starting to pop up all over the country
due to these widespread applications
of these PFASs materials,
and also at levels above the recommended
EPA health advisory limit of 70 nanogram per liter.
So the current treatment of for PFAS removal
is to use materials like granular activated carbon,
as shown here.
You might be familiar with this material
as the active material in your Brita water filter
for home purification systems.
So there are a couple of disadvantages
with using activated carbon to remove PFAS.
Some of note are that this material
is not selected for PFAS.
So activated carbon is a widely available
commercial adsorbent,
and it's very effective at removing
other co-contaminants as well.
So typically in these systems
where PFAS contamination exists,
they're in very dilute concentrations.
So you might have competition
with other co-contaminants in the system.
Also, activated carbon can not be regenerated,
and it can't be used to degrade PFAS.
So my group is using a two-staged approach.
We're first examining ways to selectively remove PFAS
from water and then using materials.
And again, applying those surface chemistry techniques
to investigate enhanced degradation of PFAS in water.
So the first approach for selective PFAS removal
is to use MIPs, or molecularly imprinted polymers.
So during polymerization,
you can include the compound of interest,
which is then later extracted
to create a polymer with an imprint
specific to the target contaminant.
So this results in a lock and key mechanism
for highly selective contaminant removal.
Another benefit to using this material
is that you're able to regenerate the polymer
for subsequent cycles of treatment.
And after recovering PFAS from water,
our group is exploring two methods for degradation.
The first uses highly, or high energy sources
to generate solvated electrons and solution.
These strong reducing agents
are able to effectively unzip the carbon fluoride backbone
to generate fluoride and solution and degrade PFAS.
So we're examining this approach
to treat PFS contaminated soil.
And then a second approach that our group is using
is exploiting these layered nanomaterials
that have historically been used
for energy storage applications,
such as lithium ion batteries.
And using them as nanocatalysts
in conjunction with a common chemical disinfectant
to effectively degrade PFAS in solution.
So what I've hoped to have shown here is the,
both the challenges that exist with
trying to increase urban water sustainability,
but also the opportunities that our group are using
to engineer novel, urban water sustainability solutions.
And again, we're doing that by thinking about
ways to design new low cost and sustainable materials
to implement them in many different ways
to address issues at the urban water sector.
And this primarily includes removal of these contaminants
that persists even after
a full advanced treatment processes.
But in the future, looking at ways to recover
value added products from waste streams,
similar to Wendy's talk with the mock material.
And with that,
I'd like to thank my amazing and diverse research group
that made all of this work possible,
and funding sources, as well as my mentors
that helped me get to this point today.
And with that, I'll be happy to take your questions.
Thank you.
Thanks so much, Jessica.
I was wondering,
I know there are a lot of different types of MOFs.
We have a MOF, or I'm sorry, not MOF, PFAS.
There are a lot of different types of PFAS.
We have a library at C&EN.
Is this approach general for all of them, for removing them?
Or is it selective for certain ones?
Right, great question.
So, right, there's over 4,000, I think,
different classifications of PFAS.
And so it's a huge problem.
And what we're currently investigating
is which template compound works best
to enhance selectivity of not just that template material,
but general PFAS in solution as well.
So that's something that we're playing around with in lab.
And someone asks,
can you sort of reclaim and recycle the template
to sort of avoid a PFAS release?
Yeah, so that's one of the benefits of using these MIP,
or molecularly imprinted polymer materials,
is that they were first designed
actually for drug sensing.
So the idea of removing the template molecule
during extraction,
and then reintroducing the polymer composite material
that we're developing into solution that contained PFAS
will result in this lock and key mechanism.
But then you can also use a simple kind of washing step
to release or desorb the contaminant
that's been attached to your MIP material
so that you essentially create a waste stream
that's concentrated, we hope, in just PFAS
and not other co-contaminants
that are going to be present in these systems.
And so once we generate a waste stream
that is concentrated with these PFAS,
then we can do the next step,
which is the degradation techniques more effectively.
Because one of the issues with
the current experimental technologies
to degrade PFAS in solution
is that you need really clean systems to do this in.
So ideally you just need water and PFAS
and whatever reactive materials
are using to degrade these compounds.
So by doing this selected adsorb desorption step
prior to degradation, we're creating essentially
a holistic approach to PFAS treatment
All right.
Someone else asks a follow up,
and you may have just answered this.
Is there a preference between acids and sulfinates in PFAS,
I guess most destruction techniques
currently favor carboxylic acid degradation?
Right, great question.
So there are differences in reactivity
between the carboxylated PFAS and the sulfinate PFAS,
our MIP material we're developing currently
PFAS that are using, or the mixed materials
that are using the carboxylate and the sulfinate
as a template materials to help capture
the two kind of main sources of the perfluoroalkyl acids.
Our degradation approaches, however,
do work for both the sulfinate and the carboxylate groups.
So that's been really promising.
All right. Well, thank you very much, Jessica.
I really enjoyed your talk
(upbeat music)
